title-group.article-title: Nonlinearity identification using sensitivity of frequency response functions

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Arak University of Technology, Arak, Iran
2School of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Hassan Jalali, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Arak University of Technology, Arak 38135-1177, Iran Email: jalali@iust.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Nonlinearities in mechanical systems demand extensive efforts both in modeling their dynamics and identification of their parameters. In this paper an identification approach is proposed for nonlinear multi-degree-of-freedom systems when there is a single nonlinear element in the system and its location is known. The proposed method is an extension of the frequency response function (FRF) sensitivity method used in the linear systems. The method uses measured nonlinear FRFs and employs a reduced order model for sensitivity calculations. Numerical and experimental case studies are used to verify the accuracy of the proposed method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Over the past decades many methods, both in time and frequency domains, have been proposed for nonlinear system parameter identification in the field of structural dynamics (Kerschen et al., 2006). The restoring force surface method is one of the earliest time domain methods introduced by Masri and Caughey (1979). This method was later developed by Crawley and Aubert (1986) and Crawley and O’Donnell (1986) and was referred to as the force-state mapping method. Masri et al. (1982) extended the restoring force surface method to multi-degree-of-freedom (MDOF) systems. The simplicity and easy-to-use nature of this method – especially in single-degree-of-freedom (SDOF) systems – has made it popular. Feldman (1994a, 1994b) introduced a non-parametric identification approach which employs the time domain Hilbert transform. His proposed method is based on the Hilbert transform of free and forced vibration responses of nonlinear systems to harmonic excitations. The varying nature of the response of many nonlinear systems can be successfully tracked by using this method.

Identification of nonlinear systems by using frequency response data, i.e. frequency response functions (FRFs) or spectra, has gained more attention over the last two decades. Many approaches have been adopted by researchers in the past for obtaining the parameters of nonlinear systems by using the frequency domain responses. One of the most general descriptions used for modeling nonlinear systems is the functional series, i.e. Volterra and Wiener series. These series, which split the relation between input force and structural response in different contributions of increasing degree of nonlinearity (Schetzen, 1980), enable the generalization of the concept of impulse response function and FRF to nonlinear systems and lead to defining the higher-order FRFs.

The use of the Volterra and Wiener series for characterization of nonlinear systems in the field of structural dynamics dates back to the middle of the 1980s. Gifford (1989) identified the parameters of a nonlinear system by surface fitting the higher order FRFs. The method that Gifford used suffers because it is hugely time consuming, although the Neural Net approach has partially overtaken the problem. Storer and Tomlinson (1993) extended the idea developed by Gifford and proposed that an FRF curve fitting approach can be replaced with surface fitting method. They used higher-order frequency response functions to characterize nonlinear structural dynamic systems.

There are many methods proposed in the literature which use frequency domain data. The reverse path (RP) method (Rice and Fitzpatrick, 1988) and the conditioned reverse path (CRP) method (Richards and Singh, 1998) are two examples of frequency domain methods. The former allows frequency response functions and local or distributed nonlinearities to be correctly estimated. The main drawback of this technique is that it requires excitation at every response location. The conditioned version of the RP method, i.e. CRP, has the capability to identify nonlinear systems with nonlinear elements away from the location of applied forces. Adams and Allemang (2000) developed the method of nonlinear identification through feedback of the output (NIFO). In this method the nonlinear forces are treated as internal feedback forces to the underlying linear system. Identification of nonlinear elements in mechanical structures by using frequency response functions (FRFs) has been considered by many researchers in recent years, i.e. Ozer et al. (2009), Carella and Ewins (2011) and Arslan et al. (2011).

Identification of nonlinear systems using structural model updating has also been considered by researchers in the past. Kerschen and Golinval (2004) used the proper orthogonal decomposition (POD) and updated the finite element model of a nonlinear structure. Meyer et al. (2003) linearized the nonlinear equations of the structure by adopting the harmonic balance method. They then updated the localized nonlinearity in a finite element model by minimizing the deviations between measured and predicted displacement responses in the frequency domain. Hemez and Doebling (2001) performed a comprehensive literature survey on nonlinear updating strategies. Recently, the sensitivity methods in finite element model updating have been presented in a paper by Mottershead et al. (2011).

The theory of model updating for linear structures has been well developed and many established strategies have been proposed. In nonlinear structural dynamics there are limited published articles addressing the parameter identification by using model updating. That is because the updating strategies developed in linear structural dynamics are not applicable in their original forms to nonlinear cases. Therefore, it seems appropriate to extend the linear methods to nonlinear structural dynamic applications. In this paper, a method is developed based on the sensitivity of the frequency response functions, and the restoring force of a nonlinear element in the system is characterized.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In the next section the proposed updating strategy based on the sensitivity of nonlinear frequency response function is presented. The nonlinear frequency response function is defined. Construction of the equivalent linear system and calculation of the sensitivity of the equivalent linear model to the parameters of the restoring force of the nonlinear element are described. In Section 3, the proposed identification approach is employed and the restoring force of a nonlinear element in a 2DOF system is characterized. Two nonlinear models, Valanis and Bouce-Wen, are considered to govern the restoring force of the nonlinear element. The proposed method is validated by using experimental results in Section 4. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 5 and references are given.

sec.title: 2.1. FRFs of a nonlinear system
sec.p: This paper deals with identification of nonlinear characteristics of an MDOF weakly nonlinear system. The equations governing the dynamic response of the MDOF system considered in this paper can be expressed as: (1)[M]{x··(t)}+[K]{x(t)}+{FNL(x(t),x·(t))}={f}cos(ωt).

M and K are respectively N×N mass and stiffness matrices of the structure. FNL(x(t),x·(t)) is a vector containing the nonlinearity and damping effects. It is assumed that the nonlinearities are localized and the location of the nonlinear element is known. Therefore the nonlinear vector can be described as: (2){FNL(x(t),x·(t))}=[0,0,…,fNL(y,y·)rth,0,0,…,-fNL(y,y·),lth…,0,0]T, y(t)=xr(t)-xl(t)

Equation (2) assumes that the system contains a nonlinear element between its rth and lth degrees-of-freedom In equation (1) {f} is the excitation vector and in this paper is considered to represent the condition of single point excitation, i.e. (3){f}=[0,…,F,…,0]T qth.

In equation (1) ω is the excitation frequency and is considered to be close to one of the natural frequencies. Under harmonic excitation and weakly nonlinear conditions, the steady-state response of the structure can be approximated as: (4){x(t)}≈{X}cos(ωt+ψ).

Having the excitation force and structural response signals measured or simulated and transferring them into frequency domain at each excitation frequency by using the Fourier transform, allows the FRF to be constructed by adopting equation (5), (5)H¯pq(ω)=Xp(ω)F(ω)ejΨ, where Hpq is the FRF of the nonlinear system between coordinates p and q and is a function of both frequency and excitation force level. Xp and F are, respectively, the amplitude of the steady-state response at coordinate p and the amplitude of the excitation force at coordinate q. ψ is the phase difference between response and force signals.

Two approaches, namely force amplitude constant and response amplitude constant methods, have been used in the literature for obtaining the FRFs of a nonlinear system when harmonic excitation method is used (Perinpanayagam et al., 2004). As the names of these methods imply, in the force amplitude constant approach, the amplitude of the applied force in all excitation frequencies is kept constant. The same procedure is followed in the response amplitude constant approach while the amplitude of structural response remains constant. The FRFs obtained by adopting the former method clearly show the nonlinearity in stiffness and damping characteristics of the structure. In fact, distortion of the FRFs and deviation of their resonant point from the resonant point of linear FRF show the nonlinearity in stiffness characteristics. In contrast, when the response amplitude constant method is used, the FRFs are similar to linear FRFs (Ahmadian et al., 2010).

The aim of this paper is to use the nonlinear frequency response function introduced in equation (5) and to characterize the restoring force of the nonlinear element by adopting sensitivity of the corresponding equivalent linear system. Construction of the equivalent linear system is explained below.

sec.title: 2.2. Equivalent linear system
sec.p: The theory of linear system identification has been well developed and too many approaches have been proposed during the past decades. For nonlinear systems, on the other hand, there are a limited number of well established identification approaches. For identification of nonlinear systems one strategy is to apply the methods developed for linear systems. The best way this can be achieved is to ensure there is an accurate equivalent linear system constructed for the nonlinear system. This strategy is adopted in this paper. In the following text, construction of the equivalent linear system is explained.
In general, the equivalent linear model for the nonlinear vector of equation (1) can be considered as: (6){FNL(x(t),x·(t))}≅[Ce]{x·(t)}+[Ke]{x(t)}

Iwan (1973) proposed to obtain the elements of the equivalent stiffness and damping matrices by minimizing the norm of residue vector, i.e. (7)min(∫t1t1+τ({ɛ}T[ρ]{ɛ})dt), {ɛ}={FNL(x(t),x·(t))}-([Ce]{x·(t)}+[Ke]{x(t)}), where t1 is an arbitrary constant and [ρ] is a weighting matrix. Iwan (1973) assumed that equation (1) possesses solutions which are periodic in t with least period τ. Performing the minimization defined in equation (7) the elements of the equivalent linear damping and stiffness matrices can finally be obtained.

Another approach for obtaining the equivalent linear model of a nonlinear element is by adopting the describing functions (Taylor and Brown, 1960). This method provides accurate approximation of the nonlinear behavior if two basic assumptions are fulfilled: (a) the input to the nonlinear element is a pure sine, and, (b) the response can be approximated by its fundamental harmonic and the effects of higher harmonics in the response are negligible. The describing functions of the nonlinear restoring force in equation (2) can be expressed as: (8)fNL(y(t),y·(t))≅(kR+jkI)y(t).

Considering that y(t)≅Ysin(τ), where τ=ωt+θ, and by adopting the optimum quasi-linearization theory one may obtain (Gelb and Vander Velde, 1968) (9)kR(Y,ω)=1πY∫02πfNL(Ysin(τ),Yωcos(τ))sin(τ)dτ, (10)kI(Y,ω)=1πY∫02πfNL(Ysin(τ),Yωcos(τ))cos(τ)dτ.

When describing functions are used, a sinusoidal input is made to yield a sinusoidal output with a different amplitude and phase. In this sense, the describing function element behaves as a linear element.

The methods described above for obtaining the equivalent linear models are applicable provided that the nonlinear elements in the system are functionally known. This is not, however, the case when identification of the restoring force of the nonlinear element is in question in a system. Ahmadian and Zamani (2009) proposed an approach which adopts the dynamics of the base linear system and the amplitudes of the excitation force and few measured structural response signals and results in an equivalent linear system. The governing equations of the equivalent linear system for the nonlinear system introduced in equations (1) and (2) at each excitation frequency ω are then expressed as: (11)[M]{x··(t)}+([K]+k¯(Y,ω)[Γ]){x(t)}={f}cos(ωt), where k¯=kR+jkI - the equivalent linear model for the nonlinear restoring force fNL(y,y·) - is a complex coefficient and Γ is defined as: (12)Γ=zeros(N,N), Γ([m,n],[m,n])=α[1-1-11],α={0, ∀ m=1:N,m≠r, n=1:N,n≠l1, ∀ m=l, n=l

Provided that the frequency responses of the nonlinear system are available, kR and kI can be obtained by solving the following equations in an iterative procedure (Ahmadian and Zamani, 2009): (13)(ωs2+[Jω]{Δk}-ω2){X¯(ω)}-([Jφ]{Δk}+{φs})T{P}([Jφ]{Δk}+{φs})=0, (14)[Jω]=∂ωs2∂{Δk}, [Jφ]=∂{φs}∂{Δk}, {Δk}=[Δkr,Δki]T,{X¯(ω)}={Xex(ω)}-∑r=1,r≠sN{φr}T{f}{φr}ωr2-ω2, where {Xex(ω)} is the vector of measured structural responses.

By adopting equations (13) and (14) the equivalent linear system at each excitation frequency is obtained. It is worth mentioning that the equivalent linear system is valid for the level of response used in equations (13) and (14). At a new response amplitude level a new equivalent linear system should be obtained. Next, sensitivity analysis of the equivalent linear system is considered.

sec.title: 2.3. FRF sensitivity analysis
sec.p: In equation (11) an equivalent linear system was introduced for the nonlinear system of equations (1) and (2) at each excitation frequency. One may extract the frequency response matrix of equivalent linear system at excitation frequency ωk as: (15)H(ωk)=Z-1(ωk)=([K]+k¯(Yk,ωk)[Γ]-ωk2[M])-1.

Considering that H(ωk)Z(ωk)=I and taking the differentiation with respect to parameter ϕ, the sensitivity of the frequency response matrix is obtained as (Friswell and Mottershead, 1995): (16)∂H(ωk)∂ϕ=-H(ωk)∂Z(ωk)∂ϕH(ωk).

Considering a set of initial values for the parameters of the nonlinear restoring force, developing equation (17) at each excitation frequency and after rearrangements, a set of linear equations of the following form is obtained (Appendix A): (18)[S]{Δϕ}={ɛ}.

In equation (18) [S] is the sensitivity matrix, {Δϕ} contains the improvements for the nonlinear restoring force parameters at each iteration and {ɛ} is the vector of differences between experimental (equations (5)) and analytical (equations (15)) FRFs at different excitation frequencies. Solving the set of equations (18) iteratively, finally the parameters of the nonlinear restoring force can be obtained. It is worth mentioning that identification by using the sensitivity of FRFs usually suffers from ill-conditioning. In order to improve the condition number of the sensitivity matrix [S], firstly, a logarithmic form of equation (17) is adopted (Grafe, 1998) and secondly, in solving equation (18) Tikhonov regularization technique (Tikhonov and Arsenin, 1977) is used.
The next section describes calculation of the sensitivity of the equivalent linear model to the parameters of the nonlinear restoring force.

sec.title: 2.4. Sensitivity calculation
sec.p: In this paper a numerical forward difference approach – as explained below – is used and the sensitivity of the equivalent linear model to the parameters of the nonlinear restoring force is calculated. By assuming a set of initial values for the parameters of the nonlinear restoring force, equation (1) is constructed. Considering that the excitation frequency is close to the sth natural frequency, i.e. ωs, and the nonlinearity is weak, one may cast the response of the system as: (19){x(t)}={φ~s}v(t). where {φ~s} is either the nonlinear normal mode obtained by using the equivalent linear system at each excitation frequency (Jalali et al., 2011) or the normal mode of the linear system, i.e. equation (1) without the nonlinear term FNL(x(t),x·(t)). It is worth mentioning that the equivalent linear system can be constructed provided that at least two experimental nonlinear FRFs are available. Substituting equation (19) into equation (1), pre-multiplying the resulting equation by {φ~s}T and after some algebraic manipulations the following equation is obtained: (20)v··(t)+ωs2v(t)+F¯NL(v(t),v·(t))=g(t), Where (21)F¯NL(v(t),v·(t))={φ~s}T{FNL(x(t),x·(t))},g(t)={φ~s}T{f}cos(ωt).

By solving equation (20) numerically at each excitation frequency, v(t) is obtained and by adopting equation (19) the response of the system is known. Having known the excitation force and response signals, the FRF is calculated by using equation (5). Substituting the calculated responses and frequency response functions in equations (11–14), k¯(ϕ) is calculated.

Next, each parameter of the nonlinear restoring force, i.e. ϕa, is changed by a small amount of Δϕa and a new value is obtained as ϕ¯a=ϕa+Δϕa. Following the procedure described above k¯(ϕ¯a) is calculated too. The sensitivity of the equivalent linear model to ϕa is then obtained by using the following equation: (22)∂k¯∂ϕa=1Δϕa(k¯(ϕ¯a)-k¯(ϕa)), k¯(ϕa)=k¯(ϕ).
In the next section the abovementioned identification approach is applied to two different numerical examples.

sec.title: 3. Numerical examples
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the 2DOF system used in this paper. The system contains a nonlinear element NL. Identification of the parameters of the restoring force of this element is considered in this section. Figure 1.
A 2-degree-of-freedom system; m1=2, m2=3, k1=100, k1=250, k3=120.
The governing equation of the system shown in Figure 1 can be derived as (23)[2003]{x··1(t)x··2(t)}+[350-250-250370]{x1(t)x2(t)}+{0fnl(x2,x·2)}={Fcos(ωt)0}

Two nonlinear models, i.e. Valanis and Bouce-Wen models, are considered to govern the restoring force of the NL element. In the following, identification of these models is discussed using the approach introduced in previous section.

sec.title: 3.1. Valanis model: single mode identification
sec.p: As a first example it is considered that the restoring force of the NL element is governed by the Valanis model. A first order differential equation as in equation (24) describes the dynamics of the Valanis model: (24)f·nl=E0x·2(1+λE0sgn(x·2)(Etx2-fnl))1+κλE0sgn(x·2)(Etx2-fnl), λ=E0α0(1-κEtE0).

The governing equations of the 2DOF system of Figure 1, i.e. equations (23) and (24), are solved numerically for the parameters given in Table 1 and the dynamic response of the system is obtained at F=1N. Having obtained the force and response signals in a frequency band around the first natural frequency, the nonlinear FRFs H¯11(ω) and H¯21(ω) are calculated by using equation (5). Now, it is considered that the nonlinear FRFs are known and identification of the parameters of the Valanis model is in question. Table 1.
Parameters of the Valanis model
κ λ E0 Et
Exact 0.6 12 100 10
Initial 0.3 21 70 6
Identified 0.6105 12.6393 99.7012 10.0690
Error (%) 1.75 5.33 –0.3 0.7

In order to identify the Valanis model parameters, first, an equivalent linear system is constructed for the nonlinear system at each excitation frequency by substituting the obtained frequency responses in equations (13) and (14). Having identified the equivalent linear system, the nonlinear normal mode {φ~s} can be calculated. Figure 2 compares H¯21(ω) and its corresponding FRF obtained by using equivalent linear system. Figure 2.
Nonlinear frequency response function (FRF) and FRF obtained by the equivalent linear system at F=1N.

Next, the sensitivities of the equivalent linear model to the Valanis model parameters are calculated. For this end, a set of initial values for Valanis model parameters are considered and equation (23) is constructed. The initial parameters are tabulated in Table 1. By using {φ~s} and adopting equation (19), a first order approximation of nonlinear system – as in equation (20) – is obtained at each excitation frequency. The obtained second order differential equation is solved, the response signals and subsequently k¯(ϕ) and H11(ω) or H21(ω) are calculated, as was explained in the previous section. Then, the parameters considered for the Valanis model are changed by a small value and a new set of Valanis model parameters are obtained. Following the above described procedure, k¯(ϕ¯a) can be calculated too. Having known k¯(ϕ) and k¯(ϕ¯a) and by using equation (22), the sensitivity of the equivalent linear model to Valanis model parameters are obtained.

Finally, by substituting H¯11(ω) (or H¯21(ω)), H11(ω) (or H21(ω)) and the sensitivities of the equivalent linear model to Valanis model parameters into equation (17), a set of linear equations – as in equation (18) – are constructed. These equations are solved and a new set of Valanis model parameters are obtained. The above described procedure is repeated iteratively until the differences between H¯pq(ω) and Hpq(ω) are at a minimum. This condition is satisfied after 160 iterations and the final parameters are obtained. Changes in the Valanis model parameters and the norm of residual vector, i.e. ‖Hpq(ω)-Hpq(ω)‖, are shown in Figures 3 and 4. The identified Valanis model parameters are compared with exact parameters in Table 1. Figure 3.
Changes in the Valanis model parameters.
Figure 4.
Changes in the norm of residual vector.

The results presented in Table 1 show that the proposed method identifies the parameters of the Valanis model with a high accuracy. The identified model should be able to predict the response of the system at high excitation amplitudes. This issue is covered in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Frequency response functions obtained from exact (line) and identified (dots) parameters, F=1N (•), F=1.5N (▪), F=2N (▴).
In the following subsection, identification of Bouce-Wen model is considered.

sec.title: 3.2. Bouce-wen model: multi-mode identification
sec.p: In this section, it is considered that the Bouce-Wen model, being described by the following nonlinear differential equation (i.e. equation (25)), governs the restoring force of the NL element: (25)f·nl=Ax·-α|x·|fnl|fnl|n-1-βx·|fnl|n.

As in the Valanis model example, the governing equations of the 2DOF system are solved numerically and the response signals are obtained at F = 0.3 N. It is worth mentioning that in this example the nonlinear FRFs are computed for both first and second modes. Having identified the nonlinear FRFs, identification of Bouce-Wen model parameters is considered. By following the procedure described in Section 3.1., the set of linear equations (18) are constructed for first and second modes, i.e. [S1]{Δϕ}={ɛ1}, [S2]{Δϕ}={ɛ2}<label>(26-27)</label> where [S1] and [S2] are respectively the sensitivity matrices corresponding to first and second modes and {ɛ1} and {ɛ2} are the residual vectors corresponding to the FRFs of the first and second modes. At each iteration, equations (26) and (27) are solved simultaneously and the vector of increments in Bouce-Wen model parameters is obtained. By repeating the above procedure, the final parameters are achieved when the sum of the norm of the residue vector, i.e. ‖ɛ1‖+‖ɛ2‖, becomes minimized. In Figure 6 the change in the (sum of the) norm of residual vector for identification using first mode, second mode and simultaneously using the first and second modes are shown. The exact, initial and final parameters are compared in Table 2. Figure 6.
Changes in the norm of residual vector, (•) first mode, (o) second mode and (□) first and second modes.
Table 2.
Exact, initial and final parameters
A α β n
Exact 100 15 15 3
Initial 60 10 25 1
Identified (1st mode) 100.1130 15.0967 14.9360 2.9150
Error (%) 0.11 0.64 –0.43 –2.83
Identified (2nd mode) 99.2257 15.2039 14.6403 3.1055
Error (%) –0.78 1.36 –2.4 3.52
Identified (1st mode and 2nd mode) 100.0104 15.4458 14.9086 3.0207
Error (%) 0.01 2.97 –0.61 0.69

The system identified in Table 2 is capable of regenerating the response at high excitation amplitudes as Figure 7 shows. Figure 7.
Frequency response functions obtained from exact (line) and identified (dots) parameters, F=0.3N (•), F=0.4N (▪), F=0.5N (▴).

sec.title: 3.3. Cubic stiffness and quadratic damping model: single mode identification
sec.p:
In order to further examine the ability of the proposed method, a non-grounded nonlinear element as depicted in Figure 8 is considered in this section. Figure 8.
A 2-degree-of-freedom system with non-grounded NL element; m1=2, m2=3, k1=100, k1=250, k3=120.

The governing equations of the system can be expressed as (28)[2003]{x··1(t)x··2(t)}+[350-250-250370]{x1(t)x2(t)}+{fnl(z,z·)-fnl(z,z·)}={Fcos(ωt)0} where the restoring force of the NL element is considered as (29)fnl(z,z·)=-knlz3+cnl|z·|z·, z(t)=x1(t)-x2(t)

Equations (28) and (29) are solved numerically and the FRFs are obtained at F=1N. It is worth mentioning that since the NL element is located between two masses and the relative displacement of two masses is small around the first natural frequency, the FRFs are obtained for a frequency interval close to the second natural frequency. By following the procedure described in Section 3.1. the parameters of the nonlinear function are obtained. Table 3 summarizes the exact, initial and identified parameters. Table 3.
Parameters of the non-grounded element
knl cnl
Exact 200 0.1
Initial 250 0.07
Identified 200.70 0.1
Error (%) 0.35 0.0

In Figure 9 the FRFs obtained by exact and identified parameters at different excitation levels are compared. Figure 9.
Frequency response functions obtained from exact (line) and identified (dots) parameters, F=1N (•), F=1.5N (▪), F=2N (▴).

Results presented in this section show that the proposed method is capable of identifying the nonlinear restoring force parameters with a high accuracy. The identified models are able to regenerate the dynamics of the system at different excitation levels. The next section considers an experimental case study.

sec.title: 4.1. Experimental results
sec.p:
In this section the proposed method is applied to an experimental case study. A schematic of the experimental test set-up is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
A schematic of the test set-up.

The test structure consists of a beam with L=603.3mm, A=200mm2 and I=416.67mm4 respectively as its length, cross-sectional area and cross-sectional moment of inertia. The material properties of the beam are: E=210GPa and ρ=7800kg/m3. The beam is clamped at one end and is subjected to a frictional boundary condition at the other end, as shown in Figure 10. A shaker is used to excite the beam into vibration in order to measure its FRFs. The applied force to the structure and the structural dynamic response is measured. The measured signals are transferred to a B&K analyzer and the FRFs are calculated.

A constant normal force P is applied to the contact interface, which prevents the right end of the beam from lateral movements. The constant force is applied by means of a suspended mass block. It is worth mentioning that the beam is allowed to rotate at this end. The dynamic response of the structure is affected by the behavior of the contact interface at the frictional support. At low excitation amplitudes, the contact interface is in stick regime and the structure behaves linearly (Ahmadian et al., 2010). Nonlinearities arise when the amplitude of the external applied force is increased, which causes the beam end to slip. At medium force amplitudes micro-slip occurs and at high force amplitudes macro-slip occurs. The aim of this section is to characterize the contact interface in micro-slip regime.

First, measurement of the linear and nonlinear FRFs was considered. The structure was excited using a low level pseudo-random forcing function and its response was measured to calculate the linear FRFs. The direct FRF is shown in the left-hand-side of Figure 11. The linear FRF is used later in this section and an accurate linear finite element model is constructed for the beam. Next, the force amplitude constant approach was adopted and the nonlinear FRF was measured. The structure was excited harmonically at different frequencies around its first natural frequency and its steady-state response and excitation force signals were measured. By using equation (5) the nonlinear FRF was calculated. Two force amplitudes – i.e F=0.2N and F=0.3N – were used in experiments and the amplitude of the applied force was kept constant at all excitation frequencies. The results of the lower force amplitude will be used for identification of the nonlinear model. The accuracy of the identified model is examined by predicting the FRF corresponding to the higher force amplitude; Figure 11 also shows the nonlinear direct FRF. Figure 11.
Linear (left) and nonlinear (right) direct frequency response functions at F=0.2N.

The results presented in Figure 11 were obtained for P=147N. The nonlinear FRF clearly shows the softening effect that is a result of the nonlinearity at the contact interface due to the micro-slip. The remainder of this section deals with identification of the dynamics of the micro-slip developing at the contact interface.

sec.title: 4.2. FE modeling and linear updating
sec.p:
A finite element (FE) model is constructed for the structure by using 49 2D Euler-Bernoulli beam elements. The boundary condition at the clamped end of the beam is considered in the FE model by removing the corresponding degrees-of-freedom. At the other end, the transverse displacement is fixed and a grounded NL element is attached to the rotational DOF in order to consider the effect of stick/slip at the contact interface. A schematic of the FE model is shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
The finite element model.

First, the NL element is replaced with a rotational spring kt and a linear model is obtained for the structure. The rotational spring models the stick behavior of the contact interface when the amplitude of the applied forces is low. kt is identified by using linear natural frequencies and adopting an eigen-sensitivity updating approach. The results are tabulated in Table 4. Table 4.
Experimental and updated natural frequencies (Hz), kt=152N.m/rad
ω1 ω2 ω3
Experimental 52.8 164.1 330.6
Updated 52.8 165.1 335.3
Error (%) 0.0 0.6 1.4
Next, identification of the nonlinear characteristics of the contact interface is considered.

sec.title: 4.3. Nonlinear contact interface identification
sec.p:
A nonlinear FE model is obtained for the beam structure by considering that an elasto-plastic Valanis model (i.e. equation (24)) governs the micro-slips at the contact interface and hence the restoring force of the NL element. Using the measured nonlinear FRF shown in the right-hand-side of Figure 11 and following the identification method described in this paper, the parameters of the Valanis model are obtained. In constructing equation (19) the mode shape of the linear model of the beam is used. Changes in the Valanis model parameters and the norm of the residual vector, i.e. Err=‖H¯pq(ω)-Hpq(ω)‖, are shown in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Variation of the error function and Valanis model parameters.

It is worth mentioning that because the sensitivity of FRF to κ is negligible compared to the other three parameters of the Valanis model, this parameter is kept constant in the identification procedure. Different values for this parameter are considered and identification is performed for each value of κ. Then the value of κ is chosen that minimizes the norm of the residue vector. The initial and identified Valanis model parameters are listed in Table 5. Table 5.
Identified parameters for Valanis model
κ λ E0 Et
Initial 0.03 500 50 16.66
Identified 0.03 1358.6 55.45 24.66

The experiimental FRF and the FRFs obtained by using initial and identified parameters (i.e. Table 5) are compared in Figure 14. In the left-hand-side of the figure the experimental FRF and the FRF obtained by identified model are compared in the force amplitude level used in identification, i.e. F=0.2N. The accuracy of the identified model is examined by predicting the FRF corresponding to the higher force amplitude, i.e. F=0.3N. The results are shown in the right-hand-side of Figure 14. The results presented in Figure 14 show the capability of the proposed method in identification of nonlinear systems by using the sensitivity of FRFs. Figure 14.
Experimental frequency response function (FRF) (solid line) and the FRFs obtained by using initial (▪) and identified (▴) parameters; F=0.2N (left) and F=0.3N (right).

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper an identification approach was proposed for nonlinear MDOF systems under harmonic excitation based on the sensitivity of frequency response functions. The method assumes that the location of the nonlinear element in the system is known. In this paper the case of single nonlinear element is considered. The proposed method aims to extend and apply the updating method based on sensitivity analysis of the FRFs, which is a well known technique in linear systems for problems with nonlinear structural dynamics. To this end, the nonlinear system was approximated by an equivalent linear system at each excitation frequency. The sensitivities of the equivalent linear system to nonlinear parameters were obtained by using a numerical forward difference approach. The sensitivity based updating approach was then adopted for parameter identification. The method was applied to different numerical and experimental case studies including grounded and non-grounded nonlinear elements. The results show the capability of the proposed method in identification of the nonlinear systems. It should be noted that the success in nonlinearity identification depends on both modeling the physics of the nonlinearity and identification of the nonlinear model parameters. Therefore the identified model obtained by adopting the method proposed in this paper can predict the dynamics of the nonlinear system at different forcing levels provided that a correct model for the nonlinearity is considered.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.p: By developing equation (17) at each excitation frequency and rearranging the resultant equations one may obtain: (30)[-{Hpa(ω1)}(∂k¯(Y1,ω1)∂ϕ1[Γ]){Hqa(ω1)}-{Hpa(ω1)}(∂k¯(Y1,ω1)∂ϕ2[Γ]){Hqa(ω1)}…:::-{Hpa(ωk)}(∂k¯(Yk,ωk)∂ϕ1[Γ]){Hqa(ωk)}-{Hpa(ωk)}(∂k¯(Yk,ωk)∂ϕ2[Γ]){Hqa(ωk)}…]{Δϕ1Δϕ2:}={H¯pq(ω1)-Hpq(ω1):H¯pq(ωk)-Hpq(ωk)}.
Equation (28) can be expressed in matrix form as (31)[S]{Δϕ}={ɛ}.
[S] is called the sensitivity matrix, {Δϕ} is the vector of increments in parameters and {ɛ} is the residual vector.
